label.title: Beyond Labels: The Art of Holistic Perception
label.description: This article examines the habit of labeling and explains how oversimplifying people—including ourselves—keeps us from seeing a person’s real complexity. We explore why labels constrain thinking, intensify negative emotions, and damage relationships, and we offer exercises that help cultivate a more holistic, nuanced view of people and the world.

texts: Labeling is when we assign a categorical, negative judgment to ourselves or someone else based on a single event or action, without deeper analysis or context.
For example:
Late to a meeting — irresponsible
Put themselves first — selfish
Lying on the couch on a day off — lazy
Failed an exam — stupid
Got fired — loser
This kind of reaction resembles a child’s thinking: they’re still learning how the world works and try to sort new information quickly.
Adults, however, can take a broader view and analyze the situation instead of drawing conclusions from a single moment.

quote.text: People love nothing more than sticking a label on someone—it frees them once and for all from the need to think.
quote.author: W. Somerset Maugham

texts: Every person is a complex, dynamic, living system. Our behavior depends on age, mood, circumstances, life stage, and hundreds of other factors.
Trying to describe a person with a single label is like retelling an entire film from a single frame: almost everything important stays off-screen.
Labeling yourself is especially destructive. It robs you of flexibility and keeps you from seeing your strengths and growing.
When we label others, we risk seeing only one facet of a person and missing everything else that makes them vivid and unique.
This can lead to conflict, misunderstanding, and distance—no one likes being boxed in.
What helps instead? Notice facts that contradict the label and consider different facets of a person.
For instance, someone cuts in line and your first thought is, “What a jerk.”
Your mood sours instantly.
But if you pause for a second and consider that they might have an urgent reason or be having a rough day, your emotions soften and your conclusion becomes less absolute.

test.question: Which of the following statements least aligns with the main idea of the chapter?
answers: Labeling helps us better understand a person’s motives
Labels can limit how we perceive a person
Labels are often based on overgeneralization and bias
Labeling can lead to misunderstanding and conflict

texts: Try a few simple exercises:
“Peeling Off Labels”
Imagine people walking around with labels on their foreheads (“loser,” “lazy,” “unattractive,” etc.). Each time you notice such a label in your mind, take it off mentally.
“Label Box”
Take a box and some sticky notes. Each time you catch yourself labeling, write it down and drop it in the box. At the end of the week, throw them all away.
You can do this in your phone notes, too.
“Replacing Labels”
Try swapping a negative label for a neutral or positive quality.
For example, instead of “stupid,” say “learning”; instead of “lazy,” try “tired and in need of rest.”
It may feel unfamiliar at first, but it builds kindness and a more accurate view.
The main goal isn’t to trade one label for another, but to gradually let go of categorical judgments and see the person—not a single word.
The fewer labels we live by, the easier it becomes to notice the true complexity in ourselves and others.

lawyer.title: Technique: Become Your Own Advocate
lawyer.description: This technique offers a fresh way to overcome self-criticism by stepping into the role of your inner advocate. Using a courtroom analogy, you’ll learn to notice accusatory thoughts, challenge them, and defend yourself with arguments grounded in facts and good faith. The method helps cultivate a more supportive, rational, and respectful attitude toward yourself.

texts: The following technique helps you work with self-criticism by inviting you to become your own advocate. It may sound unusual, but it’s surprisingly effective.
To weaken the impact of critical thoughts, it’s important not only to notice them but also to counter them with confidence.
Imagine you’re in a courtroom. Your inner critical thoughts play the role of the prosecutor, assigning labels like “failure,” “weak,” or “to blame for everything.”
Now you take on the role of the defense. Your task is to dispute the charges and show that they’re unfounded and distorted.
Picture yourself as a competent attorney. You won’t stop at “I’m a good person”—you’ll bring real facts, logical arguments, and sound explanations.
This is an inner dialogue grounded in evidence, not emotion.
Below is an example of how this can look in practice:

quote.text: Be the advocate of your inner world, not the judge of your own story.
quote.author: Elizabeth Gilbert

texts: Imagine you often criticize yourself, calling yourself weak and a failure. Now try stepping into the role of the defense—even if it feels difficult at first.
The goal is to defend yourself honestly, thoughtfully, and respectfully, as if you were defending someone you care about.
A psychologist suggests an exercise:
All right, let’s try a role-play. I’ll be the prosecutor and you’ll be the defense attorney.
Ready? Let’s begin.
(Prosecutor) Paul is weak and a failure; nothing he does works out.
(Defense) That’s not accurate. Paul earned a degree, has achieved career milestones, and is surrounded by people who value him.
(Prosecutor) But he makes mistakes and doesn’t always handle things well—so he’s still a failure.
(Defense) Mistakes are part of every human life. They don’t define a person or prove incompetence.
(Prosecutor) Fine. But he’s weak.
(Defense) Do you have evidence? Paul works hard, makes decisions, and handles difficulties. His efforts show the opposite.
(Prosecutor) He could try harder.
(Defense) If he truly lacked diligence, he wouldn’t be valued at work or considered for promotion. The claim is unfounded.
This technique works because many people find it easier to defend someone else than themselves. Here, you learn to become your own ally.
As the defense, you check facts, demand evidence, and don’t let baseless criticism pass as truth.
When negative thoughts arise, ask: “How would I defend someone I want to support?”
Approach it professionally: analyze, test the logic, and look for facts.
Here are helpful questions:
What is the charge? What exactly are my thoughts “accusing” me of?
Is there real evidence, or is this emotion talking?
What facts speak in my favor?
Can the situation be explained differently—in a kinder, fairer way?
What would a reasonable person do in my place?
Are there external circumstances that influenced what happened?
What can I say in my defense? Which qualities and achievements can I present as arguments?

lazy.title: Awakening Your Will: Why Depression Breeds Apathy
lazy.description: This article explains how depression affects motivation and the ability to act. We examine why apathy arises, how inaction intensifies symptoms, and why it’s crucial to return to activity step by step—even when you lack energy or desire. You’ll find practical strategies to gradually restore vitality, motivation, and interest in life through movement, small steps, and a new perspective on what you do.

texts: In depression, getting started can feel especially hard. It seems motivation should come first, but it rarely does. You slip into a kind of “winter hibernation,” waiting for a day when everything gets easier on its own.
Thoughts like “Nothing will bring me pleasure” or “I’ll fail anyway” can freeze you in place.
As a result, you drift further from daily life, friends, family, and the things you used to enjoy. Helplessness grows, self-criticism intensifies—and the depression deepens.
This is how a vicious cycle forms.
But it can be broken.
First, understand the nature of inaction in depression—and then learn techniques that help you regain the ability to act.
One of depression’s most insidious effects is that it seems to “switch off” your will. Difficult tasks get postponed, and procrastination becomes the default.
Every task feels too hard, motivation is absent—and the urge to do nothing takes over.
The longer this lasts, the harder the first step becomes. This state can drag on for weeks, months, even years.

quote.text: If you want to change your life, the best moment to start is the one you’re in right now.
quote.author: Fumio Sasaki

texts: Inaction is a curious paradox of human nature.
You’ve likely noticed that some people strive to live actively, try new things, and move forward, while others keep their distance from life, as if watching from the sidelines.
Here’s an interesting fact: if a person is isolated and deprived of their usual activity, signs of depression will almost inevitably appear after a while.
In depression, something similar happens—only voluntarily and gradually. It’s as if you sentence yourself to inaction. But do you truly want to live that way?
The thinking pattern in depression often looks like this:
I think about something I could do.
“It’s too hard / I won’t manage / I’ll feel bad / no one needs me.”
Sadness, anxiety, hopelessness.
Inaction or postponing.
Thus a vicious circle forms: negative thoughts → heavy emotions → inaction → even less pleasure and energy → worsening depression.
Why doesn’t motivation show up?
We often assume that without desire, we can’t do anything.
But does everything in life really happen only because of motivation? Do you always go to work with enthusiasm—or sometimes simply because it’s needed?
When we say “I have no motivation,” it often means “I don’t want to” or “it’s hard to start.”
That’s normal. We don’t have to want everything that’s good for us.
In depression, almost nothing feels appealing. You want to lie down, disappear, hide. But long stretches of inaction only deepen the suffering.
The paradox is that motivation often appears after action, not before it.
Here’s an example of a conversation with a psychologist about motivation:
You used to go to the gym regularly, and now you don’t feel drawn to it?
Yes, I just don’t want to.
What if you imagined going to the gym without motivation—simply because you decided to? Then what?
I’d probably start feeling better during the workout.
Exactly. Sometimes action creates motivation—not the other way around. You can feel tired or empty and still take a step—and get a result.
Recall moments when you did something without wanting to but felt better afterward—that experience is familiar.
When we tell ourselves, “I can’t start until I feel like it,” we get stuck. In reality, the desire very often comes after the first step.
Action generates motivation.
We’ve already noted that thoughts influence emotions, and emotions influence behavior. Change your thoughts, and new emotions—and the energy to act—can follow.
You can exit the vicious circle of inaction by gradually stepping into a cycle of activity and recovery.
